Award.AwardTitle: A New Framework for Nonlinear Dynamical Model Reduction

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this project is to apply multivariate and nonlinear time series analyses in formulating comprehensive and systematic dynamical model and data reduction framework. In this framework, smooth orthogonal decomposition will be applied to the dimension reduction of deterministic nonlinear dynamical systems and will be contrasted with other alternatives - e.g., proper orthogonal decomposition. The research approach is to test the framework on several large-scale structural and molecular dynamics models' short time trajectories, and evaluate the resultant subspaces suitability for model reduction. Reduced-order models based on these subspaces will be simulated and compared with the full-scale models, using frequency response functions, bifurcation diagrams, phase portraits, and other dynamical characteristics such as fractal dimensions and Liapunov exponents.

This framework will provide a systematic way of evaluating a particular model reduction procedure's effectiveness and its robustness with respect to the bounded variations in the system/forcing parameters, and initial conditions. This project is expected to provide new tools to study slow-time dynamics of complex engineered and biological systems (e.g., physics of protein conformational changes or folding, protein-protein association, large multi-physics dynamics, etc.). For a protein system, e.g., this methodology can be exploited in the rational design of next generation compound-antagonists. The plan also supports the curricular expansion of two interdisciplinary graduate courses, the organization of department-wide workshops on graduate research for junior and senior students, the regular organization of conferences and minisymposia, the dissemination of results through the web, personal communication, and traditional publications in top journals.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intelectual Merit

A new framework for model reduction that is based on new concepts of "subspace robustness" and "dynamical consistency" was developed and tested on several FEM models of increasing complexity  including: a four-degree-of-freedom nonlinear oscillator, nonlinear beam and plate models, and a flexible beam model with geometrical nonlinearities. The approach was also applied in the development of ROM for nonlinear control systems. In addition, the acquired expertise was used to develop nonlinear noise reduction algorithms for a noise-contaminated deterministic time series. This project has resulted in five journal papers and 11 national and international conference papers. Two more journal papers are closing completion.

Broader Impact

This project partially supported the training of a postdoctoral associate and the training of a PhD student. PhD student had broad exposure to the analytical numerical techniques as applied to complex system modeling and model reduction. By presenting findings at international conferences, and participating in educational activities, he has also acquired effective communication skills. The postdoctoral associate was exposed to a full proposal preparation cycle, a result driven research environment, and was encouraged to develop novel ideas and methodologies. He gained experience in project management, was in charge of   weekly lab meetings, and supervised two graduate students. A collaboration with Naval Underwater Warfare Center (NUWC) Newport Division was initiated and we have transferred our methodology to apply in their modeling applications. The PI spent his sabbatical at NUWC to further the collaborations.

Modified by: David Chelidze

Images (1 of )
  • The image illustrates the determination of subspace robustness for multiple realizations of modal subspaces. The blue dots reflect the modal vectors from all the subspaces, the red vector indicates the dominant principal direction, the blue vector corresponds to the second principal direction, etc.
    David Chelidze
    Copyrighted
    David Chelidze
    Subspace Robustness
  • This figure illustrates that proper orthogonal decomposition does not in general provide dynamically consistent subspaces (top right plot), while the smooth orthogonal decomposition's dominant subspace is dynamically consistent (bottom left plot).
    David Chelidze
    Copyrighted
    David Chelidze
    Dynamical Consistency
